t: Job 28
Job Tells of Earth’s Treasures
“Surely*pn there is a mine for silver And*ln a place where they refine gold.
Iron*ln is taken from the dust, And*ln copper is smelted from rock.
Man*iln puts an end to darkness, And*ln to the farthest limit he searches out The*ln rock in gloom and deep shadow.
He*ln sinks a shaft far from habitation, Forgotten*ln by the foot; They*ln hang and swing to and fro far from men.
The*ln earth, from it comes food, And*ln underneath it is turned up as fire.
Its*ln rocks are the source of sapphires, And*ln its dust contains*i gold.
The*ln path no bird of prey knows, Nor*ln has the falcon’s eye caught sight of it.
The*ln proud beasts have not trodden it, Nor*ln has the fierce*i lion passed over it.
He*ln puts his hand on the flint; He*ln overturns the mountains at the base.
He*ln hews out channels through the rocks, And*ln his eye sees anything precious.
He*ln dams up the streams from flowing, And*ln what is hidden he brings out to the light.
The Search for Wisdom Is Harder
“But*pn where can wisdom be found? And*ln where is the place of understanding?
Man*ln does not know its value, Nor*ln is it found in the land of the living.
The*ln deep says, ‘It is not in me’; And*ln the sea says, ‘It is not with me.’
Pure*ln gold cannot be given in exchange for it, Nor*ln can silver be weighed as its price.
It*ln cannot be valued in the gold of Ophir, In*ln precious onyx, or sapphire.
Gold*ln or glass cannot equal it, Nor*ln can it be exchanged for articles of fine gold.
Coral*ln and crystal are not to be mentioned; And*ln the acquisition of wisdom is above that*i of*i pearls.
The*ln topaz of Ethiopia cannot equal it, Nor*ln can it be valued in pure gold.
Where*ln then does wisdom come from? And*ln where is the place of understanding?
Thus*ln it is hidden from the eyes of all living And*ln concealed from the birds of the sky.
Abaddon*ln and Death say, ‘With*ln our ears we have heard a report of it.’
“God*ln understands its way, And*ln He knows its place.
For*ln He looks to the ends of the earth And*ln sees everything under the heavens.
When*ln He imparted weight to the wind And*ln meted out the waters by measure,
When*ln He set a limit for the rain And*ln a course for the thunderbolt,
Then*ln He saw it and declared it; He*ln established it and also searched it out.
And*ln to man He said, ‘Behold, the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom; And*ln to depart from evil is understanding.’ ”
